awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Accelerating the Discovery of Electronic Materials through Human-Computer Active Search
awd_abstract_narration:
The overarching goal of this project is to accelerate the discovery of  materials with tailored electronic properties through human-computer active search. These efforts will lay the groundwork for accelerating materials discovery, and advance the capability to control electronic properties in materials with the potential for profound societal impact. The thermoelectric and photocatalytic materials predicted, synthesized, and characterized in this research can realize societal advances in the space of energy and solar fuels. High-efficiency thermoelectric materials can revolutionize how heat sources are transformed into electrical power by eliminating the traditional intermediate mechanical energy conversions.  Earth-abundant  light-responsive catalysts are emerging as  an alternative to costly, rare metal catalysts to store solar energy as  portable liquid fuels, like ethanol. These green reactions  are enabling low-cost, carbon-neutral fuels.  The team brings together expertise in materials science, chemistry, machine learning, visualization, metadata, and knowledge frameworks to develop multi-fidelity, expert-guided active search strategies within materials science and chemistry.  Resonances among the team's existing outreach programs will broaden inclusion of students from underrepresented groups and be moderated via the Alliance for Diversity in Science and Engineering.  The work will provide cross-disciplinary training to graduate students and postdocs in all aspects of material informatics, including participating in and leading team efforts, co-mentorship of Ph.D.  and postdoctoral researchers, inclusive symposia at national conferences, and a summer workshop focused on the intersection of visualization, machine learning, ontological engineering and materials science. Through enabling the acceleration of the discovery of new materials, this project supports the goals of the Materials Genome Initiative. 

An interdisciplinary team will create a search framework for scientific discovery that leverages recent advances in material databases, machine learning, visualization, human-machine interaction, and knowledge structures. To broadly assess the efficacy of this approach, the search effort will span the electronic behavior of both molecules and crystalline materials:  (i) new organic photocatalysts for solar fuels production and (ii) new thermoelectric materials for electricity generation.  Central to this effort is the engagement of domain experts and associated feedback in a human-in-the-loop active search process. Dynamic visualizations will enable the user to (i) understand the underlying reasons why the materials are being suggested and (ii) provide a user steering capability to identify and annotate specific aspects of the explored search space. Domain-expert annotations and feedback will be parsed against a suite of ontologies, further aiding the search process by providing relational insight between features. New molecules and materials will be explored through a combination of first principles calculations and high-throughput, automated experimentation; these results will be incorporated into a continually growing open-access database. Efficiently integrating and directing evolving data-streams from experiment, computation, and human steering during the search will be achieved with a multi-fidelity active search policy. Through enabling the acceleration of the discovery of new materials, this project supports the goals of the Materials Genome Initiative.  

This project is part of the National Science Foundation's Harnessing the Data Revolution (HDR) Big Idea activity, and is jointly supported by HDR and the Division of Materials Research within the NSF Directorate of Mathematical and Physical Sciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
Over the last three years as part of the ?NSF-HDR: Accelerating the Discovery of Electronic Materials through Human-Computer Active Search,? HDR seed grant we have accomplished our proposed goals focused on extracting and structuring knowledge and more. The following is a summary of our accomplishments.

1.     Launched the HIVE4MAT ontology indexing tool, adapting the HIVE2 technological infrastructure, and added 31 ontologies (18 specific to materials science, and 13 representing general and related domains).

2.     Enhanced HIVE4MAT enabling specific labeling for associative relationship types and hierarchical relationships (SuperClassOf and SubClassOf), improved interface features, and initiated visualization updates, which will continue under ID4.

3.     Pursued research demonstrating that large amounts of valuable knowledge remains buried in unstructured scholarly big data (literature) and that NLP for knowledge extraction and the application with ontologies, specifically the HIVE4MAT, can help harness this knowledge. 

4.     Created a large scientific corpus for materials science study, which consists of over 2,600,000 scholarly articles collected from major publishers like ACS, RSC, Elsevier, and Springer Nature. The collected corpus is being used to train language models for future materials NLP tasks.

5.     Developed, tested, and advanced our deep learning NLP model for extracting materials entities such as structure/compositions, properties, characterization methods and synthesis methods, with a f1-score between 60~70%. 

6.     Created an organic materials dataset containing 855 annotated and 708,376 unannotated sentences drawn from 92,667 abstracts for materials natural language processing research.

7.     Helped to create and enhance our team?s framework for materials-data/information science interdisciplinary collaboration. The framework provides a foundation for future interdisciplinary research teams and has already informed the work pursued by members of Institute for Data Driven Dynamical Design (ID4).

8.     Explored weakly-supervised relation extraction algorithms for pursuing work on synthesis and simulation extraction. Work provides a basis for achieving higher performance for ID4 research.

9.     Investigated key knowledge types and relations in materials research (e.g., chemical structure-property, synthesis action-descriptor).

10.   Extracted knowledge on Metal-Organic Framework synthesis procedures from unstructured scientific literature.

11.   Initiated work on a research graph network for Metal-Organic Framework capturing research trends, which will be continued in ID4.

12.   Provided a research platform for 8 undergraduate students (4 materials science undergraduate students on the HDR seed grant), and 2 Drexel data science students, and 2 REU students as part of ID4 during summer ?23.

13.   Engaged 2 Drexel information science PhD students in original research, both of whom are pursuing dissertation research connected with the HDR seed grant and ID4; and engaged other materials science Ph.D. students from Colorado School of Mines and Northeastern university. 

14.   Initiated a collaboration with Elsevier, which has continued with ID4.

15.   Publications: Published 9 papers at major conferences, such as IEEE Big Data, Metadata and Semantics Research Conference (MTSR), and the Association for Information Science and Technology (ASIS&T), Association for Computing Machinery/Joint Conference on Digital Libraries/Knowledge Discovery and Data Mining (ACM/KDD), as well as key information science journals, e.g., The Electronic Library.

16.   Conference talks: Presented 11 conference talks at key conference venues connected with publications and other venues, including the ACM/Joint Conference on Digital Libraries (JCDL), Workshop on Organizing Big Data, Information, and Knowledge; Networked Knowledge Organization Systems (NKOS); and the 3rd International Conference on Data-driven Knowledge Discovery (CDKD2021), sponsored by the Chinese Academy of Sciences.

17.   Colloquiums: Presented 4 colloquiums talks to collaborative research groups (Kebotix, HDR foundation team--colloquium, and the ID4 team?seminar series)

18.   Smaller group talks: Presented 8 smaller group research talks to explore further collaboration (e.g., Elsevier, Drexel COE-Materials Science Group, INFO 821-NLP seminar series, and as part of sharing among research teams.)

 


Last Modified: 01/31/2023
Modified by: Jane Greenberg
